Some of the worst plant and refinery explosions in history have been caused by combustible dust

  • Agriculture includes tobacco, grain, sugar and fertilizer processing
  • Food processing and manufacturing
  • Fossil fuel generation
  • Manufacturing furniture
  • Processing of metal
  • Pesticide manufacturing
  • Pharmaceuticals
  • Processing plastics
  • Processing of pulp and paper
  • Operation Recycling

If industrial dust is in sufficient quantities, it will ignite an explosion when it comes into direct contact with an ignition source. Secondary explosions can occur when additional combustible particles are dispersed into the atmosphere and come in contact with heat. In fact, according to OSHA, most deaths in combustible dust explosions are the result of secondary explosions.

Combustible dust has caused some of the worst industrial disasters in recent history, including a fatal explosion that tragically killed 14 workers at the Imperial Sugar plant in Wentworth, Georgia, in February 2008. Many others were also hurt including those who suffered life-threatening burns.

Trump's administration thwarted efforts to create a mandatory standard for combustible powder in the aftermath of the Imperial Sugar catastrophe. OSHA established the Combustible dust National Emphasis program (NEP) and guidelines for workers to reduce dust hazards. Those voluntary guidelines recommend that employers:

  • Dust must be contained within your equipment.
  • Use a dust collection device to collect any dust that is not contained at the time of release.
  • Clean up any dust not contained or captured.

What are the Houston Area's Refineries and how would Lawyers help?

Ten major oil refineries are located in the Houston metropolitan area. These refineries process more than half of Texas' oil production, according to the Greater Houston Partnership. More than one-fourth the oil produced in America is processed by refineries located in Texas' other regions, such as Port Arthur, Galveston Corpus Christi Baytown and Beaumont.

This means that thousands of Texas workers are working in the refineries. The Houston Chronicle reported in 2020 that Texas as a whole boasts nearly 150,000 workers in the oil and gas industry.

Refineries play an important role in the economy of Houston and all of Texas. As a result, it is important for oil and gas workers to know their rights if they are injured in an accident or explosion on the job.

What causes construction and oil refinery accidents?

OSHA states that there are more fatal incidents at refineries than in the three other highest-ranking industries. OSHA reports that 36 refinery deaths were due to a gaseous leakage between 1992 and 2007. From these refinery accidents, 52 employee deaths 250 injuries stemmed from the incidents. It would stand to reason then, that every year an average of three people die and 16 are injured in the construction and maintenance of oil refineries. However, these numbers are deceivingly low.

In an attempt to make their plants seem safe, oil refineries hire as many contractors as possible. When reporting injuries and deaths, they do not have to "claim" contractors as they are not employees of the petroleum companies.

These are the most common causes of accidents in construction and accidents at oil refineries:

  • Explosions
  • Feuers
  • Equipment failure
  • Exposure to Chemicals

You may have the right to claim compensation if you're injured by negligence at work, be it in an oil refinery, or on a construction site. This law was created to make sure that contractors and employees can work together in safety.

Refineries and employers have a responsibility to ensure that workers feel safe while performing their duties.Call our injury attorneys today for any accident at a refinery in Houston for help filing your claim. Our firm will investigate every detail surrounding your case until we find out what occurred and who is responsible for your accident.

Refinery workers labeled as contractors often get the most dangerous jobs. If you are contracted to work at an oil refinery, you may be at serious risk. If you are injured or killed, you may be brushed off by the refinery, leaving your family without the resources you need to get back on their feet. Refineries are concerned about safety ratings and liability, not about the well-being of their labor force.

This is not acceptable. We will take action on your behalf to ensure you get proper justice for your injuries.

How Does An Oil Refinery Operate?

Refineries separate crude oil into various components called fractions. This is done by taking advantage the boiling points for each fraction. The process begins with a system called fractional distillation. The crude oil will be heated up to about 720 F. Hot liquid and vapors will enter a distillation column where the vapors cool as they rise. The vapors will condense onto collection trays of different heights. These liquids, such as kerosene, will be sent to other units for further processing. To make different types of fuel, you must manipulate the liquid molecules. By using a cracking unit, you can form a smaller chain that creates a heavier fuel. This is a basic overview showing us how an oil refinery makes different types of fuel.

You may assume that the most dangerous time for an oil refinery is when workers are producing fuel. However, during a refinery turnaround, more than 30,000 separate procedures are performed. Many people are tasked with moving explosive products in and out of position when the unit is being overhauled or updated. One mistake could result in an accident that causes you permanent physical damage. Workers must remain alert when a refinery goes through transition. They also need to follow safety protocols. Refineries spend the spring months knee-deep in maintenance, hiring contractors and preparing for summer's high fuel demand. This information will be used by our refinery accident lawyers to investigate the scene. We will make sure that the oil company is following proper safety protocol during the maintenance off-season.

In September 2005, for example, OSHA assessed BP a then-record $21 million fine in connection with the fatal Texas City Refinery explosion. After determining that BP had violated the settlement agreement, OSHA would later levy a $87 million additional fine on BP.

In addition to the above, which are called economic damages because they can be assigned a "dollars and cents" value, you are also allowed to receive non-economic damages. These damages compensate you for things that cannot be measured in monetary terms, such as:
